item.title: Rash of Taliban Attacks Leaves 20 Afghan Police Officers Dead
item.description: In one assault, insurgents besieged a government headquarters in a district capital, and 40 officials were reported trapped in an underground bunker.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: DealBook: After Fed, Bernanke Offers His Wisdom, for a Big Fee
item.description: Ben S. Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, is poised to make millions of dollars from speaking engagements this year.
item.dc:creator: By ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:credit: Michelle Siu/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ben Bernanke after addressing the Economic Club of Canada.

item.title: India Ink: Meet Modi’s Potential Foreign Policy Team
item.description: Here are some of the key players who have been named as possible members of the prime minister-elect’s foreign policy and security teams.
item.dc:creator: By JYOTI MALHOTRA

item.title: DealBook: Former Top China JPMorgan Banker Said to Be Arrested in Hong Kong
item.description: Fang Fang, who resigned amid an inquiry by the U.S. into the bank’s hiring practices in China, was recently arrested by anti-graft investigators and released.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: French Join the List of Costly Engineering Errors
item.description: Engineers at the French railway network forgot to go and measure the actual distance between lines and platforms, and it will cost about $68 million to fix the problem.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China and Russia Reach Major 30-Year Gas Deal
item.description: Capping a decade-long negotiation, the two countries agreed on Wednesday to a deal, expected to be worth about $400 billion, that would send gas from Siberia by pipeline to China.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Alexei Druzhinin/Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and President Xi Jinping of China stood during the signing of a gas deal on Wednesday in Shanghai.

item.title: Netflix Plans to Expand in Europe
item.description: Already growing in Britain, the American digital video distributor will face entrenched local competitors on the Continent — not to mention Amazon.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: The Pour: Summer’s Winners: 20 Wines for $20
item.description: In hot weather, we want to guzzle and slurp, to enjoy wine and plenty of it for its sheer deliciousness and refreshment.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC ASIMOV

item.title: Egyptian Court Convicts Mubarak of Embezzlement
item.description: Former President Hosni Mubarak was sentenced to three years in prison on Wednesday after a court convicted him of diverting millions of dollars in public money for his personal use.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who was convicted on Wednesday of conspiring to embezzle more than $17 million.

item.title: Pulse of the People: More Hispanics Declaring Themselves White
item.description: Racial identification on federal census forms point to a changing self-perception among Latinos in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By NATE COHN

item.title: Thai Military Tries to Break Political Deadlock as Foes Meet
item.description: The meeting organized by the military a day after imposing martial law was the first time that all sides in Thailand’s current political impasse sat down together.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: India Ink: Investors Await Cues on Modi’s Economic Policy
item.description: Foreign and domestic investors are keenly awaiting the appointment of the finance minister and the announcement of the new government’s first budget, while keeping tabs on speculation about a possible change in leadership at the central bank.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Arun Jaitley, a senior leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, arriving at the Parliament house in New Delhi on Tuesday.

item.title: Pakistani Military Says It Killed 32 Militants in Raids
item.description: At least 32 people suspected of being militants were killed Wednesday in what the Pakistani military said were terrorist hide-outs across the North Waziristan tribal region.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Cubs 6, Yankees 1: Second Time Around, Cubs Hand Tanaka His First Loss in Majors
item.description: The Cubs knocked Masahiro Tanaka around for four runs and eight hits, including three doubles, as he fell to 6-1.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID WALDSTEIN
item.media:description: Masahiro Tanaka (6-1), pitching in the rain at Wrigley Field in the fourth, allowed four runs and eight hits in six innings in losing a regular-season game for the first time in 43 starts.

item.title: 2 Explosions Kill Scores at Central Nigeria Market
item.description: The blasts in the city of Jos detonated within minutes of each other, leaving at least 58 people dead, and the second explosion might have been timed to kill rescuers.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Nigerians waited on Tuesday for fires to subside after two deadly blasts ripped through a marketplace filled with afternoon shoppers in Jos.

item.title: The Lede: Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too ‘Happy in Tehran’
item.description: The teenagers were forced to repent on state television Tuesday after proclaiming themselves to be “Happy in Tehran” in a music video that they posted on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: An image of the "Happy in Tehran" dancers posted on Instagram.

item.title: Video: Times Minute | Scandal at the V.A.
item.description: On the Minute, President Obama under pressure over mismanagement at veterans hospitals; wheel spinning can be rewarding for lab mice; and the youngest golfer to qualify for United States Women’s Open.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIA OSIPOVA

item.title: Memo Approving Targeted Killing of U.S. Citizen to Be Released
item.description: The Obama administration said it would release much of a memo that concluded it was lawful to kill Anwar al-Awlaki, an American who was killed by a drone strike in Yemen in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER

item.title: Memo From Donetsk: After Neutrality Proves Untenable, a Ukraine Oligarch Makes His Move
item.description: Rinat Akhmetov, the wealthiest person in Ukraine, is leading the charge against the separatists and has emerged as a formidable obstacle to pro-Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Rinat Akhmetov, Ukraine’s wealthiest man, is leading the charge against separatists.

item.title: Champions League Final Between Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid Lacks Bad Blood
item.description: Unlike those in many other European cities, derby matches between Real and Atlético have rarely descended into bitterness or, worse, violence between their fans.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Andrew Matthews/Press Association, via Associated Press

item.title: Conflict Fatigue Deepens in East Ukraine, Just Days Before Vote
item.description: Pro-Russian separatists are facing increased anger from residents, a situation that could give an enormous lift to the provisional government in Kiev before the election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A woman surveyed the damage near Slovyansk, in eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday after recent mortar attacks in the region.

item.title: Fine Line Seen in U.S. Spying on Companies
item.description: United States officials say the N.S.A. is free to spy on trade negotiators to help American trade officials, and by extension, American industries and workers they are trying to bolster.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Mice Run for Fun, Not Just Work, Research Shows
item.description: Two researchers in the Netherlands placed exercise wheels outdoors in a garden, and tracked what happened.
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society, B
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GORMAN

item.title: Petco to Stop Selling Treats Made in China
item.description: The company said it was switching such products out for treats that are made in the United States, New Zealand, Australia and South America.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Twin Bombings Kill Scores in Nigeria
item.description: Two car bombs exploded at a bustling bus terminal and market in Nigeria's central city of Jos on Tuesday, killing at least 118 people, wounding dozens and leaving streets strewn with bloodied bodies.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
